La Editorial UPV impulsa el acceso abierto y las revistas diamante en la comunicación científica | |||
| |||
El avance de la ciencia abierta está transformando los modelos de difusión del conocimiento en todo el mundo. Las universidades públicas desempeñan un papel esencial en este proceso, promoviendo prácticas editoriales que garantizan la accesibilidad, la transparencia y la sostenibilidad del ecosistema científico. En este contexto, el compromiso con el A través de su política de acceso abierto, la editorial de la Universitat Politècnica de València facilita la publicación de contenidos científicos y académicos que pueden consultarse libremente, sin barreras económicas ni restricciones técnicas. Este enfoque refuerza la misión de la universidad pública como motor de democratización del conocimiento y contribuye a fortalecer el impacto social de la investigación. Las revistas diamante, una apuesta estratégica por la sostenibilidad y la calidadUno de los ejes fundamentales de la estrategia editorial es el impulso de las revistas diamante, aquellas publicaciones de acceso abierto que no imponen costes ni a los autores ni a los lectores. Este modelo favorece una comunicación científica más inclusiva y equitativa, evitando que los condicionantes económicos limiten la participación de investigadores o el acceso del público a los resultados de la investigación. La sostenibilidad de las revistas diamante plantea importantes retos de financiación, que la Editorial UPV aborda mediante un compromiso institucional decidido y la búsqueda de mecanismos de colaboración que garanticen la viabilidad a largo plazo de estas iniciativas. El apoyo de la universidad pública y de otras entidades permite consolidar un espacio editorial de calidad, donde los principios de la ciencia abierta se materializan en publicaciones rigurosas y accesibles. La Editorial UPV como agente activo en la transformación de la comunicación científicaEl trabajo de la Editorial UPV se enmarca en un contexto global que demanda nuevas soluciones para la comunicación científica. La transición hacia el acceso abierto y el fortalecimiento de las revistas diamante requieren un esfuerzo continuado en innovación editorial y en gestión eficiente de los recursos. A través de su compromiso con estos objetivos, la Editorial UPV contribuye a que el conocimiento generado en la universidad pública llegue de manera efectiva a la sociedad, promoviendo una cultura científica más abierta, participativa y responsable. |

author: Camila Sarmiento
title: Laboratorios pierden interés en hacer estudios en Colombia: se estancó la investigación clínica
text:
Laboratorios pierden interés en hacer estudios en Colombia: se estancó la investigación clínica
En el marco del Foro de la Salud de la ANDI, el Instituto Nacional de Cancerología advirtió una pérdida de interés de los laboratorios en realizar estudios clínicos en Colombia.
Colombia atraviesa una década sin crecimiento en investigación clínica. En 2014 se registraron 85 protocolos para estudios en seres humanos; en 2024, apenas 87. El promedio de registros en los últimos diez años ronda los 90 por año, lo que evidencia un estancamiento prolongado impulsado por la falta confianza de laboratorios internacionales en el país.
En 2024, solo se reportaron 29 nuevos estudios clínicos, una de las cifras más bajas de los últimos años. Actualmente hay 361 ensayos activos, pero el número de nuevos registros cae mientras países como Brasil, México y Chile avanzan sostenidamente.
El impacto es económico y sanitario. Se estima que en 2023 al menos 7.703 pacientes colombianos pudieron haber sido incluidos en estudios clínicos, lo que habría representado un ahorro de aproximadamente 244 millones de dólares para el sistema de salud, según Sergio Prada, representante de la Fundación Valle de LiLi. Al no concretarse esa participación, el país dejó de ahorrar más de un billón de pesos.
Expertos del sector advierten que Colombia ha dejado de ser un destino atractivo para la industria farmacéutica internacional por tres razones principales: una regulación del que no se actualiza hace más de 15 años, largos tiempos de evaluación por parte del Invima —que en promedio se demora 5,1 mes para aprobar o rechazar un protocolo— y falta de articulación entre los actores del ecosistema de investigación.
“La investigación clínica en Colombia no ha tenido un crecimiento real en más de una década. Los procesos son lentos, los marcos regulatorios están desactualizados y eso hace que los laboratorios busquen otros países”, señaló Ignacio Gaitán, presidente de AFIDRO.
Además, el funcionamiento desigual de los comités de ética representa otro obstáculo. Las tarifas, tiempos y requisitos varían entre instituciones, y muchos comités enfrentan limitaciones técnicas y presupuestales que afectan su operación.
Entre las propuestas para recuperar la confianza y atraer más estudios clínicos están: centralizar procesos, actualizar la regulación con estándares internacionales, mejorar la comunicación institucional, y posicionar la investigación como un sector estratégico en salud y desarrollo.
Sin estos ajustes, Colombia seguirá perdiendo oportunidades de inversión, generación de empleo calificado y acceso temprano a tratamientos innovadores.

author: La Gaceta
title: Axel Kicillof, sobre la Ley Bases: "No hay un artículo que sea bueno para los laburantes"
text: El gobernador de la provincia de Buenos Aires, Axel Kicillof , volvió a cuestionar la Ley Bases y señaló que la aprobación de la iniciativa provocaría una "caída de ingresos, pérdida de derechos y caída del consumo". "No hay un solo artículo, más allá de los posicionamientos económicos, ideológicos o partidarios, que beneficie a la provincia de Buenos Aires. No hay un solo artículo que sea bueno para los laburantes, sectores medios y profesionales", afirmó Kicillof, durante una entrevista con C5N. Y agregó: "Milei, sin la Ley Bases, ya ha avanzado con una política económica de la que esta ley participa, y es lo que vemos: caída de ingresos, pérdida de derechos y, por supuesto, esto genera una caída del consumo. Estamos en una situación calamitosa y desastrosa". El mandatario provincial expresó su preocupación por los datos económicos del primer trimestre. "Ha caído muchísimo el consumo, hay casi 10 puntos de desempleo en el conurbano bonaerense, y pega más fuerte porque somos la provincia productiva por excelencia". "Tenemos 50% de la industria nacional y todas las medidas, inclusive este régimen de promoción (RIGI), son contra la industria nacional", alertó. También cuestionó que, en un contexto de "caída salarial como pocas veces se ha visto", el oficialismo insista en reinstalar la cuarta categoría del impuesto a las Ganancias y reducir progresivamente la tasa de Bienes Personales, "particularmente" para las propiedades en el exterior. Por último, Kicillof dijo que si se aprueba, esto llevaría a que "120.000 grandes propietarios con las fortunas más grandes paguen menos, mientras los laburantes empezarían a pagar Ganancias. La compensación de uno y otro, suponiendo que no hay más despidos, sería cada vez más reducida. Podría ser un caso de pan para hoy y hambre para mañana", advirtió. "El efecto neto es algo que conoceremos más adelante pero, ya pasado el segundo año, los cálculos de la Oficina de Presupuesto (del Congreso) empiezan a hablar de una pérdida de recursos para la Provincia. Así que si (el Gobierno) quiere contar la historia, que cuente el vaso medio lleno, medio vacío, y muestre cómo queda el vaso", finalizó.

title: Sciopero, Brescia tra disagi e proteste: \u00AB\u00C8 la lotta dei lavoratori\u00BB
text:
Oggi si fermano per l'intera giornata tutte le attività del pubblico e del privato. I lavoratori sono chiamati allo sciopero generale da Cgil e Uil contro la legge di bilancio e contro le imprese che non rinnovano i contratti, sui quali altre astensioni sono state effettuate e verranno ripetute in dicembre. Disagi, al di là dei livelli non prevedibili di adesione, non mancheranno in ogni campo della vita della città e della provincia. L'unico settore che vedrà un'astensione a singhiozzo, dopo la precettazione del ministro Matteo Salvini e il respingimento dei ricorso al Tar dei sindacati, è quello dei trasporti, sul quale peseranno comunque grandi incertezze
Il corteo, che ha preso il via da piazzale Cesare Battisti verso le 9, dopo aver percorso il centro storico (via dei Mille, Garibaldi, X Giornate, corso Zanardelli, via Cardinal Querini) si concluderà in piazza Paolo VI con gli interventi.
Riviste le tempistiche del blocco, Brescia Trasporti fa sapere che il fermo durerà dalle 9 alle 11.30 e che in questa fascia oraria si potranno verificare disguidi. Arriva e Apam, per i bus extraurbani, hanno previsto fasce di garanzia: per Arriva saranno dalle 6 alle 9 e dalle 11.30 alle 14.30, per Apam dalle 6 alle 9 e dalle 12 alle 15.
I trasporti
Sono interessati alla protesta autobus e metro mentre i treni sono esclusi e proprio ieri nel tardo pomeriggio è arrivata una nota che comunica come «è revocato lo sciopero che interessava il personale del gestore dell'infrastruttura Ferrovienord. La circolazione dei treni in Lombardia sarà pertanto regolare anche su rete Ferrovienord».
Le ripercussioni
Ripercussioni si avranno anche nella raccolta dei rifiuti e nella pulizia delle strade, oltre che nell'apertura degli sportelli Tari e degli ecosportelli. Aprica informa che i servizi di raccolta non effettuati nel corso della giornata di oggi verranno recuperati durante il turno successivo o secondo le modalità previste dal contratto di servizio: «Cittadini e attività commerciali sono pertanto invitati a seguire alcune semplici indicazioni: in caso di raccolta domiciliare, si raccomanda di evitare l'esposizione dei rifiuti per preservare il decoro urbano; qualora la raccolta avvenga tramite contenitori stradali, attenzione a conferire i rifiuti solo se i contenitori risultano ancora capienti. Infine, potrebbe non essere garantita l'apertura dei centri di raccolta comunali» scrive l'azienda.
Gli altri disagi
Nelle scuole, anche in caso di mancata adesione totale, in genere l'avviso fa in modo che i genitori nel primo ciclo tengano i figli a casa. Per le superiori si prospetta l'inghippo degli spostamenti e i ragazzi potrebbero partecipare alla manifestazione. Alla Camera di commercio di Brescia sono 117mila le imprese iscritte, i lavoratori superano i 500 mila, ci sono i dipendenti pubblici, i grandi ospedali, anche le cooperative. Una platea che potrebbe essere imponente.
L'intesa di Cgil e Uil, finita l'alleanza a tre con la Cisl, è sui temi del lavoro e del sociale.

author: Shawanda Jones
title: Holiday grief strikes Slidell before Christmas
text:
Holiday grief strikes Slidell before Christmas
Mental health struggles hit harder during the holidays. How you can recognize the signs and help someone in need
Mental health struggles hit harder during the holidays. How you can recognize the signs and help someone in need
Mental health struggles hit harder during the holidays. How you can recognize the signs and help someone in need
Friends and family are mourning the loss of a beloved retired elementary school teacher from Slidell. The St. Tammany Parish Coroner’s Office confirmed that 43-year-old Kacie Kerlec died by suicide earlier this week.
According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), one person dies by suicide every 11 minutes. Mental health experts warn that the holiday season can heighten emotional challenges, especially for those already struggling or those grieving the loss of a loved one earlier in the year.
Monique Gregoire, the coordinator of Outreach at the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) in Mandeville, highlighted the added stress many face during the holidays.
“Think about the person who just lost a loved one, and this is their first Christmas without them,” she said. “Think about the parent choosing between putting groceries on the table and buying gifts for their kids. There are so many factors.”
Monique advises watching for warning signs in those battling mental health challenges, including withdrawal, mood changes such as increased anxiety or anger, and overall isolation.
Justin Tanner, a peer support specialist supervisor and former Marine, shared his perspective as someone who has experienced depression. He pointed out that the holidays can bring survivor’s guilt for some.
“This might be a time that they look back and say, ‘I’m still here, but my family’s not,’” Tanner explained.
Both Monique and Tanner emphasized the power of small gestures in providing support.
“Just a simple knock on the door—‘Hey, how are you doing today? Just checking in’—could make the difference between someone having a very bad holiday or the best day of their life,” Tanner said.
If you or someone you know is struggling, help is available. Call or text the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline at 988 for confidential support 24/7.
National Alliance on Mental Illness: Call 1-800-950-6264, text "HelpLine" to 62640, or email NAMI at helpline@nami.org
SAMHSA's National Helpline: Call 1-800-662-4357 or text your 5-digit ZIP CIDE to 435748

author: Chuck Chiang; The Canadian Press
title: Warm weather wreaks havoc on some B.C. ski hills as lack of snow leaves trails barren
text:
VANCOUVER — British Columbia's abnormally warm winter has left local ski resorts grappling with a lack of snow during the holiday tourism season, as resorts struggle to keep runs open.
Fewer than half of Whistler Blackcomb's trails are open, while Vancouver's Mount Seymour is closed entirely while it waits for better conditions.
Warmth related to the El Niño climate phenomenon this week has pushed temperatures to record highs in regions including Metro Vancouver, Greater Victoria, the Sunshine Coast and the Okanagan.
In Whistler, 120 kilometres north of Vancouver, Environment Canada was reporting no snow on the ground on Christmas Day, compared to 40 centimetres last Christmas.
On Thursday, the Whistler Blackcomb resort reported 117 of its 275 trails were open, as well as only 42 per cent of its terrain.
Warm weather has hit Metro Vancouver's three main ski hills even harder, with Cypress and Grouse mountains operating only one or two runs each.
Mount Seymour closed entirely on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, pending more snow.
James Shalman, general manager at Apex Mountain Resort in the Okanagans, says resorts across the province are "definitely behind the 8-ball" because of the warm weather, with visitors lost during the holidays unlikely to return later in the season.
"All resorts in B.C. are very reliant on the Christmas holidays as a significant portion of their financial picture for the season," Shalman said.
"This is not something where you can make up what you're down during Christmas break. You won't make that up later in the season, even if we get amazing snowfall in January, February, March."
Apex on Thursday had about a third of its roughly 79 runs open, a stark contrast from 2022 when every run was open in the first week of December thanks to heavy snowfalls.
Shalman said Apex had significant snow-making capacity and used it to combat the lack of precipitation, but there were weeks this month where the temperatures were too warm to make snow.
"I mean, we are essentially snow farmers," he says. "We're Mother Nature-dependent, and we just have to take what we get."
At Cypress Mountain in West Vancouver, management warned skiers of "thin snow coverage" for what little of the hill was open.
Several resorts have been offering discounted passes and tickets to entice skiers to visit.
"Rain's the star of the show today," Cypress Mountain's update on Thursday said, noting that night skiing had been cancelled.
Environment Canada meteorologist Brian Proctor said that in addition to El Niño, a ridge of high pressure had created a "blocking pattern" across much of North America. That was preventing the warm air generated by El Niño from passing over mountains and continuing inland.
Proctor said it meant the warm air mass had lingered over B.C., unable to go east due to high pressure acting like "a wall."
He said Environment Canada's long-term forecast called for more seasonal temperatures to return for the first week of January, bringing potential snowfall to higher elevations in the Interior.
But Proctor said snowfall was less certain for coastal areas in coming weeks, adding that skiers and resorts should temper expectations.
"We may see potential for some snowfall," Proctor says. "But really longer term it does look like an El Niño winter at this point in time, continuing and remaining fairly significant into the early spring."
This report by The Canadian Press was first published Dec. 29, 2023.
Chuck Chiang, The Canadian Press

author: John Breeden For The Northern Virginia Daily
title: Great Stalacpipe Organ one of Luray Caverns many attractions
text:
LURAY — Bill Huffman's love for the Luray Caverns runs deeper than just the natural beauty of one of nature's otherworldly creations.
Huffman, director of marketing and public relations, has been with the Luray Caverns for 20 years and believes the memories made by families who come to see the famous attraction make it unique.
"I just love seeing families come through and connect with each other," Huffman said. "Have a good time, be entertained, learn a little bit about the natural world and the cave systems, and just have a good time while they're enjoying each other's company."
The Luray Caverns is the largest cavern in the eastern U.S. and has attracted tourists since 1878.
Larry Moyer works in operations at the Luray Caverns and manages the Great Stalacpipe Organ, the world's largest musical instrument, located within the caverns.
Moyer has been with the Luray Caverns for 42 years, and his and Huffman's appreciation for the place speaks for itself.
"Obviously, we love it here and we wouldn't have been here for so long," Moyer said.
Those who work at Luray Caverns have worked extensively to continue developing the experience, such as in 2019, when a step-free entrance was put in for better accessibility.
The finances and technology came together in 2018 to put the more convenient entrance in, and after about a year of work, Luray Caverns accommodated a more comprehensive range of accessibility needs.
While the project came together in recent years, Huffman said it's been their dream for at least 40 years to have an entranceway that made getting tourists in and out of the caverns easier.
"The new entrance has really helped us open it up to a lot more folks and have a better experience on the tour," Huffman said.
The step-free entrance wasn't a simple project, however, as precautions were taken to ensure the caverns wouldn't be damaged in the making of the entrance.
Moyer said they thoroughly studied for a year, researching any risks that would potentially harm the caverns if the entrance was implemented.
"We studied everything from wildlife to geology studies," Moyer said.
The Luray Caverns property has vastly expanded over the years, as Moyer noted it have more to offer than just the caverns.
Moyer said that while the obvious attraction is the caverns, the expanded property has allowed the site to add things such as museums, focusing on giving tourists more reasons to stay all day and even overnight.
"As the business grows, we try to grow with it," Moyer said.
Some other attractions that come with the Luray Caverns experience include the Shenandoah Heritage Village, a re-creation of a 19th-century farming community that depicts the history of the Shenandoah Valley located across the street from the caverns.
"It's quite an interesting complex over there," Huffman said.
Other additions like the Gem Sluice, the Rope Adventure Park, and the Garden Maze were put in place to further enhance the experience at the Luray Caverns.
"All of these things kind of come together to have a really unique and fun experience here at the caverns," Huffman said.
As the head of marketing, Huffman's primary focus is putting the spotlight on the caverns and its stunning beauty, making it a natural landmark.
If they can attract tourists, Huffman said that'll open the door for those tourists to see the other unique things they have to offer.
Huffman said Luray Caverns promotes the other attractions through TV and Facebook ads to show there's more to see other than the caverns.
A revamp of its website, too, launched on Nov. 17 — with the idea of better promoting the sites to see at the caverns.
"We've really tried to do a better job of showing what our whole campus has to offer," Huffman said. "It's tricky, but the caverns are the main focus."
The Great Stalacpipe Organ is one-of-a-kind as it's the only one in the world, and it is one of Huffman's key marketing projects.
Invented in 1954, the Great Stalacpipe Organ is played by activating an automated system, triggering the electronic mallets to tap the stalactites to create a musical tone.
Huffman is amazed by how the magnificent musical instrument is still in great shape as it approaches its 75-year anniversary.
"Larry keeping that great Stalacpipe Organ going is truly a feat," Huffman said.
Moyer's day-to-day duties include taking care of the organ and overseeing the basic operations of the caverns.
Yet, Moyer added, while they have their respective jobs, they all work as a team.
Huffman, a Luray native whose family grew up in the Page County area for generations, never gets tired of sharing his family's history with the world.
"I think the most fulfilling part is to see folks come and enjoy their time," Huffman said. "They can spend their time in a multitude of ways. For them to choose Luray and this beautiful Valley to come to is really fulfilling to me."
Last year, the Luray Caverns attracted tourists from all 50 states.
One of Moyer's joys of his job is chatting with tourists and finding out how far they came to see the illustrious natural landmark.
"It's just amazing to me finding out how far people do come just to come here," Moyer said. "I enjoy that. They have such a great time when they come here. Basically, 99 percent of them are always smiling and in a good mood. That helps, too."
The Luray Caverns experience might be expanding even more in the coming years, as Huffman said there are plans to build a new visitor center this fall, where tourists can get their tickets and information.
Huffman said they've also looked into building an amphitheater and planting trees to "pretty up" the caverns' parking lot.
With the 150th anniversary of the Luray Caverns coming up in 2028, Huffman has lofty plans in mind.
"Those are the things that are on the horizon," Huffman said. "I'm looking towards 2028, when it's our 150th anniversary. We'll be gearing up for that, as well, and hopefully have a big celebration that year."
All these ideas draw back to ways the Luray Caverns tries to further its already incredible experience and give tourists memories to last a lifetime.
"Our wheels are always turning," Moyer said.
Huffman also wanted to make a point that they're not just the Luray Caverns, but they support the entire Luray and Page County community, adding that the caverns aren't the only attraction in the area.
"We support the town and the county as well," Huffman said. "There's so much more to do than just the caverns."
